articles.headline: Google Plans to Buy Frommer’s Travel Guides
articles.snippet: The Internet giant is buying the travel guide maker from John Wiley & Sons to expand its local and travel search results.
articles.abstract: The Internet giant is buying the travel guide maker from John Wiley & Sons to expand its local and travel search results.
articles.lead_paragraph: 8:56 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO — Google made another foray into producing original content Monday when it announced its plans to buy the Frommer’s brand of travel guides from John Wiley & Sons to augment its local and travel search results.

articles.headline: Scrutiny for Casino Mogul’s Frontman in China
articles.snippet: An inquiry highlights how politics and profits are often intertwined for Sheldon Adelson, a major Republican donor.
articles.abstract: An inquiry highlights how politics and profits are often intertwined for Sheldon Adelson, a major Republican donor.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Sheldon Adelson, the casino magnate, needed something done in China, he often turned to his company’s “chief Beijing representative,” a mysterious businessman named Yang Saixin.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo, Neil Gough and Edward Wong

articles.headline: German Small Businesses Reflect Country's Strength
articles.snippet: The small and midsize companies of the Mittelstand will play a key role in determining to what extent the German economy will continue to provide a counterweight to the recession in southern Europe.
articles.abstract: The small and midsize companies of the Mittelstand will play a key role in determining to what extent the German economy will continue to provide a counterweight to the recession in southern Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A growing number of Germans may want to see the euro zone dissolve, but Dagmar Bollin-Flade, owner of a small machinery company here, is not among them. Like many German businesspeople, she is keenly aware of the economic benefits of a common currency — and willing to pay a price to keep the euro intact.

articles.headline: Canadian Dollar’s Strength a Factor in Autoworkers’ Talks
articles.snippet: Talks begin this week on a new Canadian Auto Workers contract as the three Detroit automakers have been scaling back their operations in Canada.
articles.abstract: Talks begin this week on a new Canadian Auto Workers contract as the three Detroit automakers have been scaling back their operations in Canada.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSHAWA, Ontario — For many in Canada, the rise of the Canadian dollar to parity with its American counterpart is more a source of anxiety than pride.

articles.headline: Helen Gurley Brown, Who Gave ‘Single Girl’ a Life in Full, Dies at 90
articles.snippet: Ms. Brown, who wrote the best-selling book “Sex and the Single Girl” and was the longtime editor of Cosmopolitan, was widely credited with being the first to introduce frank discussions of sex into magazines for women.
articles.abstract: Ms. Brown, who wrote the best-selling book “Sex and the Single Girl” and was the longtime editor of Cosmopolitan, was widely credited with being the first to introduce frank discussions of sex into magazines for women.
articles.lead_paragraph: Helen Gurley Brown, who as the author of “Sex and the Single Girl” shocked early-1960s America with the news that unmarried women not only had sex but thoroughly enjoyed it — and who as the editor of Cosmopolitan magazine spent the next three decades telling those women precisely how to enjoy it even more — died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 90, though parts of her were considerably younger.

articles.headline: Municipal Bond Rule Mired in Legislative Limbo
articles.snippet: The Dodd-Frank provision would require municipal bond advisers to put residents’ interests first but a House bill would eliminate the measure.
articles.abstract: The Dodd-Frank provision would require municipal bond advisers to put residents’ interests first but a House bill would eliminate the measure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial reform was supposed to help protect local taxpayers from getting burned by municipal bond deals. But a measure that would require municipal bond advisers to put the interests of taxpayers first has been bogged down in a rule-making quagmire in Washington for nearly two years.

articles.headline: On Wall Street, the Rising Cost of Faster Trades
articles.snippet: The advantages of the nation’s increasingly high-speed stock market are under the microscope after a number of recent trading malfunctions underscored the risks that have come with rapid changes.
articles.abstract: The advantages of the nation’s increasingly high-speed stock market are under the microscope after a number of recent trading malfunctions underscored the risks that have come with rapid changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: For several years, the Wall Street wizards who built a faster, more fragmented stock market justified their creation by pointing to the benefits it yielded for investors in the form of lower trading costs.

articles.headline: Medicare Rises as Prime Election Issue
articles.snippet: Florida is emerging as a test of the Republican Party’s gamble that concerns over the deficit will trump voters’ worries about Paul D. Ryan’s proposed Medicare overhaul.
articles.abstract: Florida is emerging as a test of the Republican Party’s gamble that concerns over the deficit will trump voters’ worries about Paul D. Ryan’s proposed Medicare overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — With Mitt Romney’s selection of Representative Paul D. Ryan as his running mate, Florida quickly emerged on Monday as a critical test of the nationwide Republican gamble that concerns over the mounting federal debt can blunt potent Democratic attacks on conservative proposals to revamp Medicare.

articles.headline: Everything Wall St. Should Know About Ryan
articles.snippet: Paul Ryan, who voted for the Glass-Steagall repeal in 1999, today says banks should not be too big to fail. And he differs with Wall Street on some other points as well.
articles.abstract: Paul Ryan, who voted for the Glass-Steagall repeal in 1999, today says banks should not be too big to fail. And he differs with Wall Street on some other points as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: He could be mistaken for a Wall Street banker. Or perhaps a hedge fund manager. Or even a managing director at a private equity firm, like Bain Capital.

articles.headline: No Longer Stagnating, Euro Zone Contracts
articles.snippet: Growth in Germany in the second quarter was not strong enough to compensate for persistent recession in Spain and Italy, data released on Tuesday showed.
articles.abstract: Growth in Germany in the second quarter was not strong enough to compensate for persistent recession in Spain and Italy, data released on Tuesday showed.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The economy in the euro zone officially shifted to contraction from stagnation in the second quarter of 2012, data showed on Tuesday, portending a recession for the region later in the year that would put even more pressure on political leaders struggling to keep the common currency intact.

articles.headline: A Giant Hospital Chain Is Blazing a Profit Trail
articles.snippet: Under private equity ownership, HCA made an aggressive push for more revenue that sometimes led to conflicts with doctors and nurses over patient care.
articles.abstract: Under private equity ownership, HCA made an aggressive push for more revenue that sometimes led to conflicts with doctors and nurses over patient care.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the Great Recession, when many hospitals across the country were nearly brought to their knees by growing numbers of uninsured patients, one hospital system not only survived — it thrived.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Reed Abelson
